properties.name: Cantina
properties.description: Posted by Brandonm29 Ave BOpening Friday, this "Old Cuba"-styled neighborhood joint plates up grub like chorizo and mojo cheese empanadas, lambs tongue sandwiches, and pork shoulder dulce de leche -- fare that\'s as Cuban/Mexican/Spanish as the neighborhood soon won\'t be.

properties.name: Central Park's Sheep's Meadow
properties.description: Posted by Brandonm Perfect place for a picnic... very popular and crowded, though. But there\'s always enough room. Anywhere in the Park is perfect for a picnic, though.

properties.name: Cote D'Or
properties.description: Posted by Brandonm225 Varick St, new yorkPrice: 1-50 Thrillist: Encaged behind 120 feet of French doors, the 120-seat Cote\'s inspired by a village in Burgundy, a place where the food\'s so saucily rich, its people are indistinguishable from the roasts on which they feast. The menu\'s fat with cow (sirloin steak, pan-seared veal skirt steak, Bourguignon Beef stew, etc) and random cow bits (fricassee of sweet bread, bone marrow w/ grilled country bread), plus heart-healthy non-beef options like bacon-wrapped monkfish, and ham. Alcohol-wise, there\'re around 50 Burgundies, a wide selection of Belgian beer, and a cocktail list that includes a truffle-infused dirty martini (the truffle: like Michael Caine with cinema, for the right price it\'s willing to appear in almost anything).

properties.name: DuMont
properties.description: Posted by Brandonm432 Union Ave, Brooklyn, NYThe Scene You want intimate? Squeeze into this cozy, casual parlor in off-the-beaten-path East Williamsburg. Young couples canoodle in mix-and-match, leather-upholstered booths, while candlelight flickers off the heavily painted stucco and wood-paneled walls. Service is friendly and well-paced. The Food DuMont\'s tiny, market-fresh menu delivers simple, well-composed plates of updated American fare. Start with one of two good, basic mixed-greens salads, then tackle a tender steak with hot and crispy, parsley-studded fries, or old, reliable "DuMac & Cheese." Daily changing specials double the size of the menu. One standout: Flaky grilled mahi mahi in a sweet lemon-saffron beurre blanc with mashed potatoes and haricots verts. Desserts--which may include tart plum shortcake or chocolate brownies--are bargains, as are the nightly changing cheese plates.

properties.name: Five Guys Burgers
properties.description: Posted by Brandonm43 W. 55th St, NYHaving a superlative regional burger chain (e.g., In-N-Out) confers certain advantages -- a cheap-great standby meal, the right to trash other regions, etc. While NYC still doesn\'t have one, we do have Virginia\'s Five Guys Famous Burgers and Fries, opening today. Thrillist - Five GuysSince 1986, FG\'s been the southeastern seaboard\'s belle-of-the-bulge, serving half-pound, hand-formed burgers, hot dogs (kosher and not), fries, and soda -- the base of a food pyramid constructed by a greedy cardiologist. Meats come with any combo of ten free condiments/toppings (from mayo and relish to fried onions and sauteed mushrooms), drink refills are gratis, and there are buckets of peanuts for patrons waiting in line/passersby hip to the buckets-of-peanuts tip. All ingredients are fresh: the meat\'s never frozen, and the fries are cut from potatoes stacked in sacks on the dining area floor, promoting all-naturalness, and...sack races.

properties.name: Five Guys Burgers
properties.description: Posted by Brandonm43 W. 55th St, NYSince 1986, FG\'s been the southeastern seaboard\'s belle-of-the-bulge, serving half-pound, hand-formed burgers, hot dogs (kosher and not), fries, and soda -- the base of a food pyramid constructed by a greedy cardiologist. Meats come with any combo of ten free condiments/toppings (from mayo and relish to fried onions and sauteed mushrooms), drink refills are gratis, and there are buckets of peanuts for patrons waiting in line/passersby hip to the buckets-of-peanuts tip. All ingredients are fresh: the meat\'s never frozen, and the fries are cut from potatoes stacked in sacks on the dining area floor, promoting all-naturalness, and...sack races.

properties.name: French Roast
properties.description: Posted by Brandonm 458 Avenue Of The Americas, New York, NYOpen 24 hours... been there over 10 years... good food, drinks, coffee, good music

properties.name: Gaucho Steak Co.
properties.description: Posted by Brandonm752 10th AveThrillist: Helmed by Calle Ocho\'s Alex Garcia and styled like an Argentine cattle ranch, GSC\'s a casual, 30-seat steakhouse with a menu that tops out at 0 -- the rib eye only costs a Jackson, while the steak sandwich\'ll run you whoever\'s on the bill.

properties.name: Hill Country
properties.description: Posted by Brandonm30 W 26th St, NYThrillist: This gigantic, high-design roadhouse is modeled after Texas\' 107-year-old Kreuz Market -- like at that institution, HC patrons\'ll order heaping piles of ribs, brisket, sausage, and slop-sopping white bread at a cafeteria-style counter. Because man cannot lard on meat alone, there\'ll be plenty of sides, e.g., Longhorn Cheddar Mac & Cheese, Chipotle Deviled Eggs, and Baked Beans w/ Burnt Ends (flavorful charred brisket nubs -- the perfect accompaniment to...a whole brisket). For authenticity\'s sake, most everything\'s imported, from the Texas post oak they use for smoking, to the Bluebell ice cream you\'ll use as a substitute for personal and professional achievement.

properties.name: Ilili
properties.description: Posted by Brandonm236 5th AveA massive, two-barred lounge-aurant with funky decor twists (sandpaper walls, bar upholstered w/ conveyor belt, etc), Ilili will specialize in contemporary Lebanese, e.g., quail w/garlic whip and lemon, and beef kafta w/parsley and mint -- menu decisions over which the neighboring Syrian restaurant denies having influenced.

properties.name: Lasagna Ristorante
properties.description: Posted by Brandonm119 Seventh Ave., NY

properties.name: Los Dados
properties.description: Posted by Brandonm73 Gansevoort StDecked out with both high-design metal chandeliers and Catholic-y Jesus nooks, Dados is a collaboration between the Double Seven guys and Sueños\' Sue Torres -- whose cheffery\'s been lauded by everyone from Bon Appetit to the mag you\'ve been "mistakenly" receiving for a decade, Working Woman. Torres specializes in updating classics, yielding dishes like Coconut-infused Halibut, Tamarind-Glazed Skirt Steak, and a Grilled Shrimp and Yucatan Pork tamale, a.k.a. the "No Kosher Nosher". The bar\'s focused on 100% agave tequilas/rare mescals, plus Mex-tails like vanilla bean and orange blossom margaritas, and the Lagerita -- with lime, simple syrup, tequila, and Dos Equis, it takes the Gordian Knot of "liquor before beer?" and hacks through it with a...plastic straw. Very soon, Dados\'ll also open an adjoining taqueria that\'ll serve tacos, tortas, etc, until late into the night, saving you from crossing 9th Avenue and bearing the brunt of that most not-awesome of collisions: your peanut-shaped noggin with some jerk\'s chocolate-colored Mercedes.

properties.name: Max Brenner
properties.description: Posted by BrandonmYou can get regular food if you want... or you can take advantage of what this place REALLY has to offer... like a chocolate pizza or the 0 "Chocolate Mess" for 4 people to share... or the two pages of hot chocolates they offer... or plenty of the other desserts in the dessert menu that\'s literally probably 4x bigger than their dinner menu.

properties.name: Milk and Cookies
properties.description: Posted by Brandonm19 Commerce St, NYAmazing home-baked cookies... warm and soft. Hidden away and undiscovered... no lines and no waits here!

properties.name: Momofuku
properties.description: Posted by Brandonm171 1st AveOpening today just steps away from its original location, the new Momofuku offers twice the space for grubbing on trademark dishes like Shrimp & Grits and Pork Neck Ramen w/ poached egg. Just as before, they proudly refuse to cater to vegetarians, and meet all green-ish demands with a hearty "momu fuk u".

properties.name: Remedy Diner
properties.description: Posted by Brandonm 245 Houston St, NYThe debut joint from the scion of an Uptown diner magnate, Remedy\'s a 24/7, reveler-friendly resource with numerous booths ample enough to accommodate the eponymous girl who picked you up at Fat Baby. Though the decor\'s sleeker than average, the grub is succor-giving comfort food, from all-day breakfast specials (2 eggs, bacon, OJ, coffee, .95), to steaks/chops/southern fried chicken, plus breads and pastries made from scratch in Remedy\'s bakery -- challah! There\'re also pastas and classic sandwiches, plus more adventurous eats like Pan Seared Mediterranean Sea Scallops -- because after drinking like a fish, might as well eat like a nurse shark. Come Spring, Remedy\'ll have outdoor seating, and are currently working on their beer and wine license -- because for the true alcoholic, the only real comfort food is a late night snack of keep-drinking.

properties.name: Sakae Sushi
properties.description: Posted by Brandonm405 Lexington AveThe US debut of a renowned Singaporean chain, Sakae\'s a large, earth-toned fish-ateria that ushers out its cold plates on NYC\'s longest kaiten-sushi -- like a luggage carousel, though it\'s unlikely Sakae will lose your edamame in Cleveland. Just as impressively, you can order hot plates like noodle/rice bowls and Japanese steamboats via computerized menus at each table (because in Singapore, if you can\'t be trusted w/ Bubbilicious, you\'re not getting anywhere near a waitress). The entire op\'s managed by chefs from Singapore, with assistance from a custom-made "sushi robot", which monitors conveyor belt speed, sets the pace at which plates leave the kitchen, and once got busy with an arcade prize game (Claw-job?).

properties.name: Sea
properties.description: Posted by Brandonm

properties.name: Serendipity 3
properties.description: Posted by BrandonmNY Times - Okay, so the lamps aren\'t really Tiffany, and the chili on the foot-long hot dog is for wusses. There aren\'t many places left that make you want to blow bubbles through an ice-cream-soda straw. Serendipity 3 is proof that life isn\'t always a cabaret -- sometimes it\'s a sweet-sixteen party. Half Provincetown antique-queen attic, half Mad Hatter tea party, it\'s one of the few spaces kids like that doesn\'t have a ride. And stupid drinks like apricot smushes, big burgers, and towering sundaes mean that they might even shut up and eat. But 3 has one chilly bowl of magnificence that would render the place a must-visit if it was served atop a Dumpster. Frozen Hot Chocolate -- please don\'t try to make sense of it, just sip it, slowly -- is what Cristal might taste like if it came in a flavor called fudge brownie. It\'s like riding the Cyclone and giving a hickey: You have to do it at least once in your life.

properties.name: Southern Gourmet Pantry
properties.description: Posted by Brandonm529 Hudson St, NY, NY 10014SO SO GOOD!! Great southern comfort food. Best Chicken Pot Pie i think i\'ve ever had. Great mac & Cheese, too

Kids love it. Lots of comfy seating. Never feels crowded because its so big inside.

properties.name: Zaragoza
properties.description: Posted by Brandonm215 Ave A, NYThrillist: At first glance, ZMD\'s nothing more than a tiny checkout counter and some shelves stocked with canned goods and cassettes of bands you might\'ve once heard in, say, a Mexican deli. But behind the register, its ridiculously friendly employees have spent all day stewing up beef/chicken/lamb/pork to stuff into tamales, tortas, and tacos so tasty you\'d willingly spend .75 on them. There\'re also 11 seats in back, where you can leisurely watch televised soccer and drink 32oz Coronas you\'ve pulled straight out of the beer cooler -- so casual it feels like it should be illegal, and will be if you execute your plan of pretending you didn\'t take any.
